Experimentally
Issue with hackmd: you can only edit in raw markdown form, and you can't click links in raw markdown form, so it's kind of a pain to follow links.
I told @Josh Triplett this already privately, but I recommend the "split mode" for clicking on links.

BTW, @T-lang, A few reminders we didn't get to in the meeting. There are some items that might just need a few check-marks:

  • Needs checkmarks?
    * add IntoFuture trait and support for await #65244

  • Some recent additions:
    * Make handle_alloc_error default to panic (for no_std + liballoc)
    * Stabilize the #[alloc_error_handler] attribute (for no_std + liballoc) #66740

Some recent additions:

Got some concerns about these two; will try to find some time to write em up

Also, @T-lang and others, meeting starting now
Can’t come immediately
Not sure if I’ll make it at all.
minutes posted
Sorry for the delayed response. Couldn't make it today due to conflicting meeting in SF.
Regarding 65244, no strong reason, just need to read in detail and understand, and Pin has made me really feel out of depth about future types.

@Josh Triplett ok -- this is more of an ergonomic "nice to have" then a deep item. It basically says that when you do foo.await, you can supply a future, or something that can be converted into a future.
much like for x in y the y can be an iterator or something that can be made into an iterator
It's a fairly shallow syntactic lowering thing rather than a type-system thing

this is useful because sometimes you have builder patterns, primarily, and it means that the builder can "become" a future when it is awaited, versus having to always be usable as a future; since futures have internal state, it's nicer to be able to transform into a future
otherwise you have to maintain the internal state in your builder the whole time, when it really makes no sense

@Josh Triplett I'd recommend looking at https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/65244/files#diff-05b568c9c95e597ae295649f9072177e , in particular: https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/65244/files#diff-05b568c9c95e597ae295649f9072177eL526

@T-lang triage meeting now!

https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/74595 nominating this for a discussion in a triage meeting. Basically, const eval in repeater position can leak how type parameters are used internally by the function, seems bad
Note that enum discriminant values have the same issue
what do you mean?

luckily still requires a feature gate

#![feature(arbitrary_enum_discriminant)]
const fn foo<T>() -> usize { 42 }

#[repr(usize)]
pub enum Test<T> {
    A = foo::<T>(),
    B(T),
}
fun
This reminds me
when we discussed const eval, we talked a lot about the "meaning of unsafe",
but I feel like we didn't talk much about the general "semver" questions, right?
e.g., how much is a const fn allowed to change? (not at all?)
maybe this is all settled but I don't know the answers :)
I'd like to be able to go to a FAQ or "design doc' or something on wg-const-eval and find them...
right, its inevitable with const generics that if a const fns output changes it could cause a downstream crate to stop compiling
(e.g, if T<true>: Trait but T<false>: Trait doesn't resolve, if a const fn flips from true to false for an input it could break a crate)
but changing the implementation without changing the output shouldn't break anyone ideally
Yeah, imo changing the internals of a const function shouldn't change anything at its call site (ignoring auto trait leaks with impl trait for now)
But changing the return value is a breaking change :laughing:

It is less bad than I thought, so this works

fn test<T: Bar>() {
    let _ = [0; T::ASSOC];
}

trait Bar {}

impl Bar for u16 {}
impl Bar for (u8, u8) {}

trait Fez {
    const ASSOC: usize;
}

impl<T> Fez for T {
    const ASSOC: usize = 4;
}

but this breaks:

fn test<T: Bar>() {
    let _ = [0; T::ASSOC];
}

trait Bar {
    const ASSOC: usize;
}

impl Bar for u16 {
    const ASSOC: usize = 4;
}
impl Bar for (u8, u8) {
    const ASSOC: usize = 4;
}
there are probably more realistic examples for this
The planned way to allow the second example and std::mem::size_of::<T> in constants used in types is https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/213817-t-lang/topic/const.20equality.20.2B.20wf

A more interesting example of why the current state is not ideal

trait Foo {
    const ASSOC: usize = 4;
}

impl<T> Foo for T {}

// works
fn test1<T>() {
    [0; T::ASSOC];
}

// does not work
fn test2<T: Foo>() {
    [0; T::ASSOC];
}

@T-lang to summarize my current understanding of both the problem and how we probably want to fix this I wrote https://hackmd.io/aZYPCFBBTyOdKTrqqy4Q3g .If someone has a question about this please PM me or just ask here.

Agenda

Any chance to look at "expand/resolve: Turn #[derive] into a regular macro attribute " at the next meeting?
It's a small change from the language point of view, but it's blocking other work.

I'm pretty frustrated about this specific delay because nominated the PR on Nov 22 (that's more than a month before the Catholic Christmas) and built my plans on Rust work during New Year holidays around having it merged before that time, so all the plans were broken.
It has been discussed multiple times at triage - the comment from @Taylor Cramer was sort of a summary of the various discussions.

@Vadim Petrochenkov I'm sorry that we ended up missing that timing.

At this point, consensus was that we are ready to merge as soon as the PR addresses the primary issue @Taylor Cramer summarized: preventing derive from appearing before other attributes, preserving that existing restriction, to avoid both the observable cfg evaluation side effect and the possibility of other attributes seeing and becoming dependent on the specific evaluation of any particular derive. That may be liftable in the future, but not right now.

(We originally talked about prohibiting derive() as well, but I don't think we can do that; it could break existing valid code.)
Does that seem like it'd be reasonable to add to the PR?

Josh Triplett said:

and the possibility of other attributes seeing and becoming dependent on the specific evaluation of any particular derive

I've answered to this bit in https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/79078#issuecomment-754981810, #[derive(Trait)] doesn't expose the code generated by Trait to the following attributes.
I'll re-add the restriction because it still allows to punt on the questions about empty derive() and cfg_eval.

@Vadim Petrochenkov Ah, I see; you're right, the generated code isn't an issue. But yes, avoiding the issue of expansion (whether via derive() or via derive(SomeTrait)) is still a good reason to prevent out-of-order derive. We'd still be willing to consider out-of-order derive, but that'll take more consideration and thus more time, whereas without that this is something we can approve right away.

@T-lang meeting!
@scottmcm Thanks for bringing up else match, by the way. While I personally don't want to have that construct, it does seem strictly preferable to implementing typestate just for this.
I think there are other reasons we might want typestate in the future, but I don't think we should do it just for this construct.
Yeah, I'm not actually advocating for it, but I think else match like that is the best way to handle the use case while still remaining a basic desugaring.
